headline: Homemade Beef Stew
description: This homemade beef stew recipe for the stovetop is seasoned with rosemary and parsley for a hearty and delicious dinner. It's even better the next day!

video.description: See how to make a classic stovetop beef stew.
video.name: Beef Stew VI

name: Homemade Beef Stew
recipeIngredient: 4 stalks celery, cut into 1 inch pieces

recipeInstructions.text: Heat oil in a large pot or Dutch oven over medium-high heat; add beef and cook until well browned.

Dissolve bouillon in 4 cups water and pour into the pot; stir in rosemary, parsley, and pepper. Bring to a boil; reduce heat to low, cover, and simmer for 1 hour. Stir in potatoes, carrots, celery, and onion.
Dissolve cornstarch in 2 teaspoons of cold water; stir into stew. Cover and simmer until beef is tender, about 1 hour.

review.reviewBody: Very flavorful and easy to prepare.

With the addition of a little salt, the flavor of this stew was good. For our preferences, there wasn't nearly enough thickening, even after doubling the corn starch. The vegetables weren't nearly done enough after the hour on low, at which point I turned the heat to medium and had to cook another 15-20 minutes. Thanks for sharing this recipe!

I love the simplicity of this recipe. I had to make some substitutions, Herbes de Provence instead of rosemary and parsley, tapioca flour instead of cornstarch and bone broth instead of beef broth. I thought the flavors were excellent

The first time I did this recipe, I stuck pretty close to it as written. My wife loved it, much better than her dad’s tomato-based stew. I change it up every time I make it now, usually leaving out potatoes, adding mushrooms, red wine, garlic, and egg noodles. It’s always a winner. Note: you can get the stew done in less time using an instant pot or other pressure cooker. Do the first step with a 15 minute pressure cook and 15 wait before releasing steam. I’ve done this with tougher cuts of meat and they’ve come out great.
Made this recipe numerous times. My favorite simple beef stew recipe. I add basil and garlic to it. But otherwise, perfect.
Really fantastic. I seasoned and floured the cubes of meat before searing. I also added about 1/2 cup of red wine as well. Flavor was delicious!

Simple recipe with nice taste. Our preference was for a thicker liquid base, so I modified the cornstarch quantity and I used Better Than Bullion instead of bullion cubes. The directions are excellent and the timing made the meat perfectly tender.
Very good., I added more carrots (but we love carrots and never have enough ) I Also added a dash of cayenne pepper ,just enough to gice it a tang,but not to make it hot. Thanks

I enjoyed this recipe I made a few minor adjustments I brown my meat in a skillet first until each side has a nice crust then I cook my celery in the same pan using the oils remaining from the meat until transparent. I don’t like crunchy celery in my food I added a can of diced tomatoes and juice Then I added my potatoes to the same skillet with the celery and a slice of butter to brown my potatoes a tad. It prevents them from turning into mush and adds great flavor. I use a tablespoon of the flour mixture I made to sear my meat, a tablespoon of the oil from my skillet 3 tablespoons of water mixed well and added it all to the pot and cooked on low for an additional 2 hours. I omitted corn starch Great hearty flavor Great thickness to gravy Very savory and meat extremely tender. Total cook time 3 hours
This is now a family favourite, easy to make and very delicious. I use a cast iron dutch oven, great recipe.

Instead of bullion I use Campbell beefy mushroom soup . After browning meat I put in my veggies and a shallot and crushed garlic pour on soup mixture w/ 1 can water then cover Dutch oven and put in oven for 1 1/2 hrs @350
Added 1 cup of red wine
it's a hardy beef stew on a cold day !

This was easy and really tasty on a cold damp Pennsylvania winter evening. I did substitute 1 cup of the 4 cups of water for 1 cup of a Hazy Double IPA from a local brewery. I can't say it made it better but after downing the rest of the can I really didn't care... LOL. So, you can either take my word for it that this is a really good recipe or you can give it a whirl yourself. I hope that my attached photo helps. Can you taste it? YUM!
Yummy, made about five meals for me my husband. Works great in a thermos for my husbands' lunch ,especially with 20° temps

I liked the ease of few ingredients, simple mixtures, and adjustable recipe. I followed the Chuck Sampson review notes on browning the beef and ended up getting my Mom to admit how good it was even though it wasn’t her recipe! Thank you Paul and Chuck.
Rather bland.
Simple to make but delicious. My kind of recipe

Great tasting, easy. I would recommend using liquid beef broth or stock instead of bouillon and cook down (reduce) instead of adding cornstarch. Think about adding small rutabaga, turnip, and/or 1 parsnip for subtle taste enhancement (all chopped).

I added meatballs (see the recipe titled "Chef John's Meatballs"-- I just swapped the herbs from "Italian" to rosemary, sage, & thyme) to this recipe, and left the skin on the potatoes, and it was one of the most savory foods I ever made! Already stocking up ingredients for several batches this fall and winter!

I used leftover pork for this recipe, so I put everything in at once and cooked it for an hour. Adding 2 TBLS of Worcestershire sauce was a great idea I picked up from other reviewers. I left out the onion and celery since I didn't have any and added the leftover corn from the previous night's dinner. Still came out great. If you're worried about your potatoes falling apart from over cooking, leave the skins on and just cube them.
Love it and my family loves it!
9-23-22 I may be a little biased as I don’t like dishes that are not spicy, but, I really think this dish lacked flavor. Added additional salt and red pepper flakes and still oh hum.
Good favor but the meat was overcooked.

I have made many stew recipes, and this is hands down the winner! The combination of seasonings, especially the rosemary, knock it out of the park! I do add 2 cups of red wine and reduce the water accordingly, otherwise I make the recipe as written. Yum yum. Leftover portions freeze beautifully. It's lovely to have delicious comfort food ready in minutes when it's been a long day.
I 100% agree with sly50's rating comment

I have made this stew recipe multiple times i have added garlic and sometimes exactly as written it is a favourite in my home. I do add a little extra cornstarch to thicken more and I think it also makes a big difference using good rosemary and pepper (no stale or dollar store spices)
Excellent beef stew! Easy recipe too..The only thing I changed was using flour and water to thicken the stew instead of cornstarch

This recipe is a good starting point for a stew. Loved the method of cooking, but it definitely needs stuff added to it- for example, salt. But also, some bacon or garlic, some acidity with lemon juice or vinegar, rustic bread on the side. Great recipe to build on!
This is good but I thought it was too much works for more than 2 hours.

I made this recipe exactly as it was written. The only adjustment was extra cornstarch/cold water at the end. I'm not sure how it has received such a high rating. It ended but being a soup, not stew. The required one hour was not enough time for the celery to cook, but the meat was super tender (because it had been boiled for two hours). The seasonings were basic, it made the house smell good but the flavor was lacking. This is a good starter stew recipe - but needs several adjustments.

Good stew, but better with additional ingredients. I used 2.5 lbs of beef instead of 2, used 3 c. of water and 1 c. of red wine instead of 4 c. of water, 2 tbl of ketchup, 2 tbl of Worcestershire sauce, a splash of Gravy Master, salt and pepper to taste, and I used 4 tbl of starch and water. Served over a bed of white rice. Wonderful comfort food during this lock down!
I substituted with 1 cup of beer, an extra teaspoon of cornstarch/water and no celery. Meat was very tender, potatoes, carrots were perfect...5 stars
Best recipe ever.
Was delicious. Just didn't add the rosemary.
Very easy...very tasty

I left a review earlier. I gave it 3 stars because there is no thickness; it's liquid like soup so that really disappointed me. I cannot edit my review so I am leaving a new one. 

Although I felt like I had to add a lot more cornstarch and leave it sit for a few hours to thicken up, I have to say, this has PHENOMENAL flavor so I feel I should give it another star. Not sure if the flavor is from leaving it sit and cook for a few hours or if it would have tasted the same if I didn't.

Just know that as the recipe is written, it is a soup. It's liquid. After adding several more tsps of cornstarch, it thickened.

This stew is simmering on the stove right now, so I can’t fully rate it yet, but it smells really good! The reason I’m commenting is because I have noticed many people saying the stew wasn’t thick enough. I just noticed the recipes says to add the cornstarch/water mixture prior to the second hour of simmering. I think this may be part of the problem. You see, cornstarch is a great thickener, but if boiled/simmered too long, it can actually break down and lose its thickening ability. My suggestion is to wait until the last 10 minutes of cooking to add the cornstarch/water mixture. That will give the perfect amount of time to thicken the stew without the danger of it breaking down. This is what I plan to do when mine is almost done cooking. I will report back to comment on the final result!
This recipe is very good. I used Russet potatoes by mistake and they proved too soft for stew. But the stew itself is very tasty.
Definitely 5 stars! Made the recipe as stated and it came out perfect! The meat was very tender and I paired with white rice. Next time I’ll probably add more cornstarch for a thicker consistency.

Way too salty... I followed the other reviews for the changes...but if in canada.. only add 2 bullion cubes to the 4 cups otherwise it is way too salty. Other than that it is delicious.. but the boyfriend said for the leftovers he will add water to make it less salty
Amazing!!! I’ve made this since my baby was an infant she is now 7 years old I love the creator of this recipe. You’re amazing and we all thank you!!
It is pretty basic tasting, nothing special IMO

I loved it! I added a steak seasoning to the meat along with the paprika and pepper and added two extra bouillons but otherwise I followed the recipe. For leftovers, I steamed rice to serve it over because the potatoes were gone! Yummy!!
I loved this stew. I added a little more corn starch to thicken it a bit.
I added basil, brown sugar and a little red wine to spice up the flavors.
This was an excellent recipe. I used 1 cup of red wine in place of the beef stock, and also used 2 sprigs of fresh rosemary instead of dried. Delicious ??

I use beef round instead of cubed ‘stew meat’. Standard stew meat from the store is a combo of who-knows-what cuts of extra meat the butcher ends up with; this is no way to select stew meat that will be certain to end up tender! Get a round roast and trim excessive fat, leaving a fair amount for flavor, and cut into desired size cubes.
Really good recipe in original form. I have adjusted it over many trials to this:
Instead of beef bullion, I use 4 tsp of Better than Bullion Beef Base and 1 tsp of Better than Bullion Roasted Garlic base. HUGE improvement for stews!

I also add:
1 tsp of smoked paprika
1 Tbsp Worcetershire
1 tsp dried thyme
1 turnip, cubed to 1/2” +/-
1 can sweet peas
1 Tbsp ketchup (a squeeze from a tube of tomato paste is better if you have it)
1 Tbsp of a good vinegary hot sauce such as Pickapeppa (I use a locally made sauce called Bustellos, but it’s no longer made and all but impossible to find any more-I have a case)
1/2 cup good pinot noir

I coat the meat in a mixture of flour and all the dry seasonings and brown in a cast iron skillet until a good crust appears on the surface. Deglaze the pan with the wine and some of the water to get all the tasty crunches in the pan!

Sly50: We are asked to mention changes made and people do want to know about them. I have been making this for years. I use 2 cans of beef broth and 1 can water instead of cubes. I add additional spices of garlic powder or minced garlic, onion powder, 3 dried bay leaves and Kitchen Bouquet. We like a lot of veggies so I add more than this recipe calls for. To thicken I use flour for a better texture, IMO. If I still want it thicker, I add potato flakes.

Loved this! Pretty much followed the #1 reviewer with flour, onion and garlic powders, and pepper on the beef before browning. I used Better Than Bouillon (roasted beef) in place of the cubes, and used one quarter of total liquid to be merlot wine and the rest water. Threw in a good pinch of herbes de Provence, along with extra rosemary. Simmered for about 1 1/2 hrs. Added a few red potatoes, carrots, and celery in about 1 inch pieces, along with about 1/2 onion chopped. Added a few shakes of Worcestershire, and a big dollop of concentrated tomato paste (from a tube). Wow, tasted the sauce before covering it and it was delicious! I don’t know if it was the Merlot, the Better than Bouillon or what, but it was sooo flavorful, unlike my usual slow cooker stews with canned broth. I won’t go back to those anymore!!! This is THE beef stew I want to make always. Maybe I’ll throw in pearl onions and mushrooms next time.
Delicious and simple.

This stew is very good and very easy. I taught my oldest son to make it and now he makes it all the time. Based on others reviews and my own previous experience I did not add Rosemary and instead substituted my own spices that I know my family prefers. Awesome stew though!! And it’s the only recipe I will make for beef stew now!

I made this and it as a hit. I did substitute 1 cup of Cabernet Sauvignon for 1 cup of water. My wife thinks I'm a great chef! Ha! But this is a great recipe and I'll use it again and again. Very simple too!
Tasted incredible!!

I followed the recipe pretty much as written except I did three bouillons and added some hidden valley ranch seasoning to the stew meat. Cooked this in the crockpot on low for 6hrs and the meat was falling apart. I made cornbread to go with it and it was delicious!!
Very tasty. The beef was very tender. I did add canned beef broth the ai had on hand but only 3 cups so I did add some bouillon and water. Otherwise I followed exactly. I will surely make this again.
Made this....did a few things differently but it came out amazing!
I added more vegetables.

Came out beautifully slow cooked. I seared the beef in the Insant Pot until brown, then added onions and celery. There's a carrot shortage where I am so we used frozen peas and carrots. I added beef flavored Better than Bouillon (2 heaping tablespoons' full), some Compton's Gravy Salt, gravy browning, worcestershire and a few teaspoons of tomato paste. For thicknesd, I left it in the Instant Pot on the slow cooker setting for seven hours but I think six would be ideal. I understand some people don't like recipe modifications but I do. So enjoy.
It came out thicker than we thought but delicious.

It is certainly a good stew, is it as good as some of the reviews claim, NO. I admit I did not have the rosemary so maybe that would have made a huge difference but it is not the best stew I have ever eaten. It does require at least 5 times the cornstarch called for as other reviewers have said.
This is my favorite stew recipe by far! I did add a little thyme & some mushrooms. I’ve also used flour when we were out of cornstarch.
Love this recipe! Meat is nice and tender and wonderful flavor! My favorite stew recipe to date!

Absolutely delicious stew! I did follow the suggestions below the recipe and I halved the recipe so I used a tablespoon of flour along with spices to coat 1 lb of stewing beef before it was browned. I browned the beef and added gravy cubes to the water along with 1/2 cup red wine to simmer for an hour. I used the vegetables in the recipe and added a cubed baby eggplant which I had in the fridge. One of the best stews I’ve had and will definitely be making this again.

I forgot to read the reviews before making it, but I did read them in time to use more corn starch to thicken the gravy to my liking. I also used beef stock instead of water and only 2 bullion cubes. It was very good! I threw in some fresh mushrooms I had in the fridge.
Great flavor, I took out the celery and added onion. I also made mine a little thinner.

I love the stew recipe. When I make it I add a turn up a can of tomatoes, a splash of Ketchup, lots of garlic and a little more water. The fun thing about this recipe is that I make it different every time. It gives me to comforts of home, like being a kid again. I love sharing.?

Very good recipe. I doubled everything & used Better than Bullion in it instead of cubes. Only downside was it was pretty watery even though I doubled the starch & water. Ended up adding flour & water. Next time, maybe some red wine too:)

All I can say is yum yum yum!! I followed a few recommendations in the reviews by adding wine, A-1,catchup and Worcester, increased corn starch to thicken gravy and Voila perfect and yummy. Thanks to all the reviewers for your input. ?
This is a keeper!

The best beef stew recipe I have ever tried. I am a vegetarian so when I am cooking a meat dish for my husband I usually rely on sight and smell. I have made this recipe 3 times now and hubby has been thrilled with it each time, especially the day 2 and day 3 leftovers.
Really easy to make and tasty!

Delicious!!! The only thing I added, based on other reviews, was the ketchup, worcestershire & A-1 close to the end of cooking time. Takes a little time but so worth it! We finished it off with Mexican Cornbread.

Great and easy! I used more beef, about 2.5 lbs (that's what my package was). I used more broth, about 6 cups. I used a little to deglaze, then added 4 cups of broth. When I added the veggies, I added 2 more cups. I added more carrots, celery and I used 3 lbs of golden/yellow potatoes so I didn't need to peel them. I added 3 TBS of the cornstarch & water mixture. I added 2 TBS of A1 and Ketchup, 1 TBS of Worchester sauce. Towards the end, I used my potato masher to break down some of the veggies and meat to make it a thick stew.
I added mushrooms because mushrooms are always a good idea and 1 TSB of cinnamon to bring out some higher notes of flavor.
This stew turned out perfect!
Oh

I also made this by dredging the beef in seasoned flour. Came out perfectly thick enough. Used beef stock instead of bouillon, so I had to add salt at the end. After 2 hours, everything but the carrots were properly cooked. Also doubled the seasoning, which was good except for the pepper. It makes a lot! So I probably won't make this regularly for dinner.

Love this recipe. Easy to make, easy to substitute! Really like this with parsnips as well instead of celery. I don't cook it the full 2 hours, once the potatoes are soft we chow down. Makes the house smell amazing for days! Tastes great the next day too. Freezes well! Best with rolls or biscuits.
Delicious!!
I added a little flour to thicken the broth and an extra potato cause I like them. Next time I'm going to get a little more brown on the meat.
Very good recipe. I didn't add the celery. I did add a little cumin and fresh cilantro. The cornstarch and water was not enough. It didn't thicken it at all.

Very nice stew. I tossed the meat in flour as suggested, browned in the Dutch oven, added 1/2 c red wine to 3 1/2 c broth. Added mushrooms and peas along with two dashes of worcestshire the last hour (cooked total of 3). 3tsp corn starch in 3 tsp cold water thickened it nicely. 
I realize it’s not the original recipe, just knew these additions would go well.
It was very bland. I will look through comments for adjustments before trying this again.

My absolute favorite beef stew. DELICIOUS
I substituted 1 qt beef broth for the water and only used 2 bullion cubes. Omitted the corn starch (don't use it).
Made this as directed and it turned out so delicious!!! Simmering the meat and broth for an hour made the meat so tender and flavorful. My family loved it!!!
I made this exactly like the recipe said , and was great , my family love it ,.
I think next time I will add some red wine for a little more flavor. Wasn’t as thick as I’d like and added plenty of corn starch.

This is a very simple yet tasty stew. Even my less tender cuts of meat come out tender. The changes I had to make due to allergies were to not use bouillon but deglaze the pan with a little cooking wine after browning the meat. Then I add some Worcestershire sauce and boiling water to the pan, enough to equal the needed liquid. Salt and pepper to taste and that's it

This was very good and easy. I made it without celery because I didn’t have any. The only trouble was that when Allrecipes halved the recipe for me, the amount of water was incorrect. It changed to 1 tsp instead of 2 cups. I didn’t catch that until after the meat cooked for the first hour...I’m just a tsp of water. However, it all turned out ok when I added the water with the veggies, and it tasted great.
This was so good! We are it up in one sitting! I filled the recipe and other suggestions of adding wine for 1 cup w

This was my first time ever making Beef Stew. I made sure and seared the meat first then let it sit aside, while I had the onions etc going. Now I must admit I slow cooked this in my instant pot for 4 hours then pressure cooked for 27mins and this came out amazing. I severed it with Lettuce and fresh sourdough bread. I would differently make again. what I love most about this type of Dish is that you can add as much veggies as you want. Oh and the beed was just amazing in the instant pot. ONE POT FOR EVERYTHING
Very tasty, made a few changes but nothing major

I have been making beef stew for years but this is hands down the best one. Following other reviews, I shook the meat in seasoned flour and browned. Deglazed that skillet with broth and red wine. Added a1 and Worcestershire sauce. Seriously so good!!

Very tasty stew. Traded the dried rosemary for two stalks of fresh rosemary and added green beans. I tried to cut down cooking time but it took 2 hours as advertised to make the proper consistency. Maybe I'll try less water next time.

Great winter meal. Didn't and wouldn't change a thing. Awesome recipe. So simple and quick to prepare. I served this recipe with a loaf of crusty French bread... great eating! This recipe is a definite keeper.
absolutely beautiful!!!

This did not come together as anything more than the sum of its parts - beef, potatoes, carrots, celery, broth. More like soup than stew. Watery and bland. Wished I'd followed my instincts and added garlic. There are a lot of interesting suggestions, but I don't think I'd bother making it again. My husband is convinced it will taste better on day 2.

I saw this recipe and decided to try it. I substituted a couple of bayleaves for the rosemary because I was out , but other than that followed the recipe exactly . I served it with simple baking powder biscuits . Everyone I fed it to loved it and it was a great comfort meal on a dreary fall day.
